repnme.cdata!: Sierra Leone - Health Sector Investment Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings for the project were as
            follows: the outcome was satisfactory, the sustainability
            was unlikely, the institutional development impact was
            substantial, and the Bank and borrower performance were both
            satisfactory. The lessons learned indicate that the risk
            assessment needs to be taken into account in the
            project's scope and innovative design particularly in
            post-conflict settings. Ensuring flexibility in project
            design: the flexibility in the initial project design
            (annual plan basis) allowed for immediate financing of
            emergency activities when needed, without immediate
            restructuring. Distributing funds over too many activities
            can lessen the project's overall impact, specially when
            resources are limited, and should be avoided. The financing
            by the project of contractual staff for key implementation
            positions has ensured continuity of project implementation,
            in a conflict/post-conflict environment where most civil
            servants were no longer in place. Activities should not be
            included in the project when funds to finance them are not
            secured. In the project planning process, it is crucial to
            ensure that required counterpart funds are commensurate with
            the country's capacity to make them available. The need
            to recruit local consultants for long-term assignments
            whenever feasible. The need to further tighten internal
            fiduciary control measures. It is particularly important
            when project management is fully integrated within a
            Ministry to assign specific responsibilities for project
            implementation and decision-making on the Ministry's
            more permanent staff rather than on those who are likely to
            change more often such as political appointees. Finally, in
            post-conflict settings, one cannot expect short/medium term
            sustainability and it is important that Donors commit their
            resources over long periods to give a sector a reasonable
            chance for take off.

repnme.cdata!:
Sierra Leone - Integrated Health Sector
            Investment Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Integrated Health Sector Investment
            Project will support the Government's National Health
            Action Plan (NHAP) core program. The project has the
            following objectives: a) improve key health status
            indicators; b) increase access to health care and family
            planning; c) improve quality service through training,
            supervision and improved logistic support; d) strengthen
            management, accountability and community involvement at
            central and peripheral levels; and e) increase efficiency
            and improve financing for health care. Project components
            include: 1) improving child health; 2) improving maternal
            health; 3) reducing fertility; 4) reducing the incidence and
            prevalence of communicable diseases, including HIV; 5)
            reducing mental illness; 6) reducing injury and handicaps;
            7) assuring satisfactory nutritional status; 8) reducing
            drug abuse; 9) improving living conditions; and 10)
            improving food hygiene.

Sierra Leone - Integrated Health Sector
